thread.title: Women hold 36 percent of executive roles in legal pot industry: survey - Chicago Tribune
thread.title_full: Women hold 36 percent of executive roles in legal pot industry: survey - Chicago Tribune

author: Alexia Elejalde-Ruiz
title: Women hold 36 percent of executive roles in legal pot industry: survey - Chicago Tribune
text:
Is the marijuana industry fertile ground for women in leadership?
Women make up about 36 percent of executives in legal marijuana businesses, according to a new study from industry publication Marijuana Business Daily.
To compare, women hold 21 percent of senior leadership positions in the U.S., and less than 6 percent of those are CEOs, though the rates vary greatly depending on the industry, according to a survey released earlier this year by Grant Thornton International, which polled 5,400 business leaders worldwide.
At Fortune 500 companies, women represent 25 percent of executives or senior managers and less than 5 percent of CEOs, according to Catalyst, a nonprofit that promotes women in business.
Women are particularly well-represented in some divisions of the cannabis industry, including testing labs, where they hold 63 percent of high-level posts, and processing and infused-product manufacturing, where they hold nearly 48 percent of senior jobs, the new survey found.
Still, women hold less than half of senior roles at two-thirds of cannabis businesses, and one in four companies have no women at the executive level. Marijuana investment and wholesale cultivation companies have the fewest women in executive roles, at 28 and 33 percent, respectively.
Marijuana Business Daily based its findings on answers from 632 cannabis professionals and executives who responded to an online survey.
Dina Rollman, co-founder of Illinois Women in Cannabis, a nonprofit dedicated to promoting women's roles in the industry, wrote in an email that she was encouraged by the survey but believes the numbers would be "drastically lower" in Illinois.
"Through my various roles within the Illinois industry, I have observed a dearth of women in C-suite roles," said Rollman, who is a founding member of the Illinois Cannabis Bar Association, a board member of the Illinois Cannabis Industry Association and Chief Compliance Officer for GTI-Clinic Illinois Holdings, which has two cultivation licenses and one dispensary.
She sees great potential for female executives in cannabis because it is "too new to have a glass ceiling," with no institutional barriers to keep women from rising to the top.
"Illinois has no shortage of female accountants, attorneys, insurance experts, finance executives, commercial bankers and other professionals to fill executive-level positions at medical cannabis companies," she said. "I hope that as the industry develops in Illinois, we see women holding 50 percent, if not more, of the leadership roles."
